review.title: A Distance-Based Decision in the Credal Level
review.abstract: Belief function theory provides a flexible way to combine information provided by different sources. This combination is usually followed by a decision making which can be handled by a range of decision rules. Some rules help to choose the most likely hypothesis. Others allow that a decision is made on a set of hypotheses. In [6], we proposed a decision rule based on a distance measure. First, in this paper, we aim to demonstrate that our proposed decision rule is a particular case of the rule proposed in [4]. Second, we give experiments showing that our rule is able to decide on a set of hypotheses. Some experiments are handled on a set of mass functions generated randomly, others on real databases.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Faith Function Theory [2,9] enables us to represent all kinds of ignorance and provides rules for combining several imperfect pieces of information provided by different sources in order to obtain a more coherent one. Combination process helps us to make later decisions. Decision-making consists in selecting the most appropriate measures to be taken for a given problem. Today, we often face the challenge of making decisions in cases where information is inaccurate or even unavailable. In [12] Smets proposed the transferable belief model (TBM) as an interpretation of faith theory. TBM emphasizes a distinction between knowledge modelling and decision-making. Accordingly, we distinguish between the credal level and the pignic level. At the credal level, knowledge is presented as faith functions and then combined. Pignistic level corresponds to decision-making, a stage in which faith functions are transformed into probability functions.

sections.text: This decision rule helps in selecting the most likely hypothesis based on the calculation of the distance between a combined bba and a categorical bba.
